description: From Middle English false, fals, from Old English fals (“false; counterfeit; fraudulent; wrong; mistaken”), from Latin falsus (“counterfeit, false; falsehood”), perfect passive participle of fallō (“deceive”). Reinforced in Middle English by Anglo-Norman and Old French fals, faus. Compare Scots fals, false, Saterland Frisian falsk, German falsch, Dutch vals, Swedish and Danish falsk; all from Latin falsus. Displaced native Middle English les, lese, from Old English lēas (“false”); See lease, leasing. Doublet of faux.
The verb is from Middle English falsen, falsien, from Old French falser, from Latin falsō (“falsify”), itself also from falsus; compare French fausser (“to falsify, to distort”).

entries.meaning: Not faithful or loyal, as to obligations, allegiance, vows, etc.; untrue; treacherous.
examples: a false friend, lover, or subject;  false to promises

entries.meaning: Not well founded; not firm or trustworthy; erroneous.
examples: a false conclusion;  a false construction in grammar

entries.meaning: Not essential or permanent, as parts of a structure which are temporary or supplemental.
Used in the vernacular name of a species (or group of species) together with the name of another species to which it is similar in appearance.
examples: false powderpost beetles (members of Bostrichidae not in Lyctinae)

adverbs.description: false (comparative more false, superlative most false)

entries.meaning: In a dishonest and disloyal way; falsely.
One of two options on a true-or-false test.
examples: The student received a failing grade for circling every true and false on her quiz.

verbs.description: false (third-person singular simple present falses, present participle falsing, simple past and past participle falsed)

entries.meaning: (electronics, telecommunications, of a decoder) To incorrectly decode noise as if it were a valid signal.
(obsolete) To violate, to betray (a promise, an agreement, one’s faith, etc.).
(obsolete) To make false, to corrupt from something true or real.
